divs: sighting detailsmarch 5, 2010, 11:15 pm willingboro, nj 08046 - my wife and i had just dropped off our eldest daughter at the emergemcy room at lourdes- rancocas hospital. the emergency parking lot was full, so we parked across the road in the north building lot, facing south. the sky was unusally dark, with only the moon visible to the rear of my left shoulder and two stars to my right. this may have been due to all the light in the area. while sitting there in the car, i noticed a light that i at first thought to be an airplane, being close to both philadelphia (15 miles west) and the macguire afb\fort dix complex (20 minutes to the east). there were no other aircraft visible until after the light disappeared. the light appeared to be a long way off in the distance and was visible slightly above a guy-wire on an electrical pole on the opposite side of the street. there were no contrails and due to distance and being in the car, we were unable to determine if there was any sound. i called my wife's attention to it after a while as it had not disappered in a few minutes. we could not determine the size or shape, but it seemed to give off a sparkle or twinkle every now and then almost like an aircraft. this continued, in a due south direction until 12:39 am march 6, when it finally disappeared into the lights on the side of the building and behind the building itself. i figured it to be a satellite or the international space station, very large, to be visible for such an extended period of time and distance. it looked like no aircraft that i had experienced in the us air force or naval reserves. it also did not resemble the five disc-shaped ufos that i saw with my brother-in-law in montclair, nj in september 1959. they went from horizon to horizon is approximately 15 seconds, in a jerky, start- hover fashion. they were in echelon formation and the left inside wing craft was oscillating, as though it was having control problems. i decided to report this just in case someone else saw the same thing early this morning.
Summary: Star-like light with sparkle/flash travelling southward until obscured by building
trends: There have been no other sightings in Westampton
This sighting has never been favorited.
